title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Our quest
Background


Mixed-effects models have become increasingly common in  applied linguistics (Gries, 2021)

Powerful, state-of-the-art statistical tools

Improve accuracy and generalizability of our analyses
Enhance our ability to model real-world scenarios





Yet, many researchers are still not comfortable using them

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Our quest
Workshop‚Äôs aims


To become familiar with mixed-effects models




To learn how to implement them using easy-to-use statistical software

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Our quest
Workshop‚Äôs aims


To offer an accessible introduction to mixed-effects models in linguistics




To provide a practical introduction to running mixed-effects models:

Free, open-source statistical software ‚Üí JASP

‚ÄìConfucius

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Introduction
What is a statistical model?


Representation of reality

Mathematical representation of data generating process  (Field et al., 2012)





Used to make predictions about real-world phenomenon




Must represent the data collected (observed) as closely as possible

To reduce errors in prediction





The closer the model represents the data collected

The better the fit of the model

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Introduction
What is a statistical model?


All statistical procedures

Essentially the same model
Variations of this basic model:





Outcome = (Model) + Error

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Introduction
Example of a statistical model


Simple statistical model ‚Üí Mean

Hypothetical value ‚Üí Doesn‚Äôt have to be observed in the data
Model (prediction) ‚Üí Mean value used to summarize the data




Outcome = Mean + Error

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Linear regression
Regression line


Regression line ‚Üí Single line that best fits the data

Has the smallest overall distance from the line to the points
Indicates strength and direction of association among variables





Outcome = Intercept + Slope * predictor + Error

Regression line

Intercept ‚Üí Baseline
Slope ‚Üí Rate of change



Outcome = Intercept + Slope * predictor + Error

Outcome = Intercept + Slope * predictor + Error

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Linear regression
Basic modeling assumptions


Linearity

Linear relationship between outcome and predictors (constant change)





Normality

Errors (not variables!) ‚Üí Normally distributed  (least important)





Equal variance (Homoskedasticity)

Errors (residuals) ‚Üí Constant variance (i.e., variability)





Independence

Errors (residuals) ‚Üí Independent (i.e., uncorrelated): Fundamental

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Making the case: Mixed-effects
Violation of independence assumption


Results in artificially low p-values ‚Üì (biased)

Type 1 errors go ‚Üë









Source: Economics

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Making the case: Mixed-effects
Dealing with dependencies in linguistic data


Traditional way of analysis:

Modeling aggregated data (i.e., ignoring dependencies)

Standard, single linear model for all participants






Aggregation

Means ‚Üí Entered into the analysis
Subject and item variability ‚Üí Collapsed

Model ‚Üí Understimates variability (i.e., Loses information)
Model ‚Üí Has less information to work with!

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Making the case: Mixed-effects
Data visualization: All data points

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Making the case: Mixed-effects
Data visualization: Means

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Making the case: Mixed-effects
Aggregated vs.¬†unaggregated data


Aggregated data ‚Üí One data point for each subject




Unaggregated data ‚Üí Multiple data points for each subject





Aggregated (wide format)
  subject                       Mean_RT
1   S_101                          8.75
2   S_102                          8.42
3   S_103                          8.19
4   S_104                          8.46
5   S_105                          8.64

Unaggregated (long format)
  subject                           RT
1   S_101                         9.59
2   S_101                         8.67
3   S_101                        10.14
4   S_101                         9.55
5   S_101                         9.17

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Making the case: Mixed-effects
Summary: Costs of ignoring variability


Loss of information:

Reduction of statistical power (i.e., ability to detect an effect if it truly exists)





p-values ‚Üí Artificially low ‚Üì

Increase of Type I error rates ‚Üë
Overstimation of effects





In short:

Our inferences can be seriously compromised (less accurate)





Solution:

Innovative method ‚Üí Mixed-effects modeling

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Pair work

Formulate a question about what we have seen so far

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Mixed-effects models
It‚Äôs all in the name!


Terminology:

Variance components
Random intercepts and slopes
Random effects
Random coefficients
Varying coefficients
Varying intercepts and slopes
Hierarchical linear models
Multilevel models (implies multiple levels of hierarchically clustered data)
Mixed effects models

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Mixed-effects models
What they are


Extension of traditional regression

But can incorporate all kinds of dependencies into the analysis





Examples of nesting and dependencies:

Students within classes (within schools)
Observations within people (e.g., longitudinal data)
Observations within pairs
Patients within hospitals
People within cities
And so on‚Ä¶

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Mixed-effects models
Standard regression


Intercept ‚Üí Baseline
Slope ‚Üí Fixed effect




Outcome = Intercept + Slope * predictor + Error

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Mixed-effects models
Mixed-effects model


Intercept ‚Üí Baseline
Slope ‚Üí Fixed effect



New ‚Üí Random effect(s) (i.e., grouping factor, e.g., participant)



Outcome = Intercept + Slope * predictor + Error



Outcome = Intercept + Fixed effect + Random effect(s) + Error

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Mixed-effects models
Advantages over traditional methods


Allow researchers to avoid averaging over the data




More flexible ‚Üí Can deal with other types of outcome data (e.g., binary)




Handle missing data and unbalanced designs very well




Allow estimation:

Multiple effects on outcome variable (e.g., the effect of age and  feedback on language scores), and
Individual variation within and across subjects and items





Put simply, they allow simultaneous modeling of fixed and random effects

Hence, the name ‚Üí Mixed-effects models

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Mixed-effects models
Fixed effects


Account for variation due to experimental factors




Represent average effects ‚Üí Population-level effects

Do not change or vary across groups or over time





Factors with limited, repeatable levels (e.g., group membership)




Basically the same condition effects ‚Üí Standard regression

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Mixed-effects models
Random effects


Account for variation due to collecting data from a random sample  of a much larger population

Account for variability within groups





Represent how much average effects (trends) vary across levels of  some grouping factor (e.g., participants or items)

Particular groups might behave differently from the average





Should have at least 5 levels

More levels ‚Üí Preferable (Brown, 2021)





Intrinsically categorical (Winter, 2019)

Mixed-effects: Estimate interpretation
Random effects (new)

Slope ‚Üí Fixed slope (i.e., the effect = -0.28) varies SD = 0.40 across classes

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Regression modeling
Analyzing reaction times


Aim:

To test if sentence grammaticality affect reading times of L2 learners
Outcome variable: Reaction times (rt)
Two-level predictor variable: grammatical (GR) vs. ungrammatical (UG)





Hypotheses:

H0: No difference in means of RTs
H1: Longer (slower) RTs for UG than GR stimuli (Murphy, 1997)





Research design:

Within-repeated-measures

All participants judged the grammaticality of all sentences

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists

Incorrect = 0

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Logistic mixed-effects modeling
Modeling a binomial outcome


Accuracy

As a categorical variable:

Violates assumption of linearity (binary outcome)






Linearity

Linear relationship between outcome and predictors
Changes in predictor ‚Üí Constant, proportional changes in outcome

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Logistic mixed-effects modeling
Modeling a binomial outcome


Standard linear model ‚Üí Cannot be fit



Y = b0 + b1* X + Œµ





Logistic regression model:

Considers categorical nature of outcome
Transforming outcome (Y) ‚Üí Continuous scale (log odds)
Predicting probability of observing the outcome (Y = 1)

1 / 0

In practice, Y can be any two values:

successes / failures
presence / absence

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Logistic mixed-effects modeling
Modeling a binomial outcome


Aim:

To test if learning condition affect accuracy of L2 learners
Outcome variable: Accuracy: correct (1) vs.¬†incorrect (0)
Two-level predictor variable: incidental vs. intentional





Hypotheses:

H0: No difference in performance between groups
H1: Intentional group will perform better (Kang et al., 2019)

title: Introduction to Mixed-Effects Modeling for Linguists
text:
Concluding remarks
Mixed-effects modeling


Independence assumption ‚Üí Fundamental




Aggregation conceals data variability




State-of-the-art, flexible method:

Accounting for variability in linguisitic data

Simultaneously model participant and item effects







Consequently, our results are closer to the truth.
